edge: Anastasia Steele is an English literature major at Washington State University Vancouver in Vancouver, Washington.

When her roommate, Kate Kavanagh, catches a cold and is unable to interview Christian Grey, a twenty-seven year old billionaire entrepreneur for the college newspaper, Ana agrees to take Kate's place.
At Christian's Seattle headquarters,
Soon after, he visits the hardware store where Ana works and offers to do a photo shoot to accompany the article she had interviewed him for.
Christian asks Ana out for coffee, but leaves abruptly after she confesses to being a romantic, saying he is not the man for her.

node_2: first edition copies of two thomas hardy novels
edge: Christian later sends her first edition copies of two Thomas Hardy novels, including Tess of the d'Urbervilles, as a gift

After drinking too much, she calls Christian, saying she is returning the books, and berates him for his behavior towards her. He goes to the bar to find her, arriving just as her photographer friend, José Rodriquez, attempts to kiss her against her will.
After considering the non-disclosure agreement and negotiating her own terms, Ana and Christian spend the night together.
While considering the non-disclosure agreement and negotiating her own terms, they briefly visit his 'Red Room', a place stocked with a bed and a variety of whips and shackles.
introduced Christian to dominant practices at age fifteen
was and still is a friend of the family, despite Christian keeping their relationship a secret
Christian bestows gifts and favors upon Ana, such as a new car and a laptop
Ana and Kate move to Seattle
insists that Ana goes over his contract before moving forward
wants more than the one-sided relationship Christian is proposing
becomes angry when Ana mentions leaving for Georgia to visit her mother
meets Ana's mother in Georgia

Ana enters Christian's Red Room after returning home.
Ana and Christian have a night in his Red Room.
Christian remains emotionally distant, upsetting Ana.
In an effort to understand Christian's psychology, Ana asks him to demonstrate the worst punishment he would inflict on her for rule-breaking.
Christian whips Ana with his belt, making her count each stroke out loud.
Crushed, she declares her love for him,
but says his behavior is unacceptable.
He replies that he is too screwed up to have the relationship that she wants.
Devastated and depressed, Ana leaves Christian,
and he promises to send her a check for the car he sold without her consent.
As he goes after her, their eyes lock and she holds his gaze, saying his name as the elevator doors close.
